story.name: Poste de travail FreeBSD, 2ème partie : configuration initiale
story.author: Ed Hurst
story.p: Il s'agit de la seconde partie d'une série d'articles d'introduction. L'auteur explique comment mettre en place X et le serveur de courrier électronique postfix.

story.name: Apple dévoile l'OS Panther
story.author: Blake Hoo
story.p: Apple Computer a récemment annoncé la sortie de son tant attendu Mac OS X 10.3 Panther, basé sur FreeBSD 5.

story.name: Une année en revue : turbulences, difficultés et succès dans le marché des OS
story.author: Matthew Cooney
story.p: Une rétrospective de l'année 2003 sur plusieurs systèmes d'exploitation, parmi lesquels FreeBSD.

story.name: eRacks annonce un portable Centrino(TM) pour Linux/FreeBSD
story.author: Communiqué de presse eRacks
story.p: eRacks Open Source Systems annonce un portable basé sur Centrino(TM) qui supporte FreeBSD.

story.name: L'anniversaire des 10 ans du système d'exploitation FreeBSD : Silicon Valley est vivant et vivace !
story.author: Matt Olander
story.p: Le communiqué de presse de offmyserver.com au sujet de la surprise-partie célébrant l'anniversaire des 10 ans de FreeBSD.

story.name: Poste de travail FreeBSD : 1ère partie, l'installation
story.author: Ed Hurst
story.p: Dans cette première partie d'une série d'articles d'introduction, l'auteur montre comment utiliser le programme d'installation de FreeBSD.

story.name: Utiliser SNMP et RRDTool avec FreeBSD
story.author: Avleen Vig
story.p: Un guide pour générer les statistiques d'un serveur fonctionnant sous FreeBSD 4 et 5.

story.name: Les 10 ans de FreeBSD : Succés de la surprise-partie
story.author: Eugenia Loli-Queru
story.p: Un rapide compte-rendu plus quelques photos de la soirée.

story.name: Interview : Greg Lehey du AUUG
story.author: Howard Dahdah
story.p: Un entretien avec Greg Lehey, développeur FreeBSD.

story.name: De Linux à FreeBSD : Une critique de FreeBSD
story.author: Gabe Yoder
story.p: L'auteur passe rapidement en revue FreeBSD 4.8 et le compare avec GNU/Linux.

story.name: L'impression pour les impatients
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: L'auteur donne des détails quant à l'utilisation de Apsfilter pour l'impression.

story.name: La reflexion d'un utilisateur sur FreeBSD 4.9
story.author: Corey Holcomb-Hockin
story.p: L'auteur examine FreeBSD 4.9, décrit comment le mettre à jour pour corriger les problèmes de sécurité et intégrer les corrections de bugs et comment compiler un noyau sur mesure.

story.name: Améliorer les mots de passe utilisateurs avec apg
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: L'auteur explique comment améliorer sa gestion des mots de passe grâce à des mots de passe générés automatiquement.

story.name: Entretien avec le programeur FreeBSD de jail
story.author: Tech JVDS
story.p: Pawel Jakub Dawidek, un des programmeurs des jails de FreeBSD, donne son point de vue sur les jails.

story.name: FreeBSD comble les lacunes avec la version 4.9
story.author: Michael Singer
story.p: L'auteur donne un court aperçu de FreeBSD 4.9-RELEASE.

story.name: FreeBSD 5.1
story.author: Jem Matzan
story.p: L'auteur examine FreeBSD 5.1-RELEASE et le compare avec GNU/Linux.

story.name: Un bébé dans les bois : Un utilisateur Linux migre vers FreeBSD
story.author: Ed Hurst
story.p: L'auteur relate l'expérience de sa migration de Linux vers FreeBSD.

story.name: Un système de mise à jour binaire automatisé pour la sécurité sous FreeBSD
story.author: Colin Percival
story.p: Dans ce papier, l'auteur décrit un sytème automatisé pour compiler et distribuer les mises à jour binaires liées à la sécurité sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Netcraft : BT l'hébergeur le plus fiable du mois de Septembre
story.author: L'équipe web theWHIR
story.p: La dernière étude de Netcraft révèle que sept des treize entreprises d'hébergement internet les plus fiables pour le mois de Septembre utilisent FreeBSD.

story.name: Utiliser les ACLs sous FreeBSD 5.X
story.author: Grzegorz Czaplinski
story.p: L'auteur explique comment créer et configurer les permissions d'accès uniques sur les fichiers et les répertoires en utilisant les Listes de Contrôles d'Accès (ACLs).

story.name: Monter son propre clone Segway FreeBSD
story.author: Adamson Rust
story.p: Trevor Blackwell a conçu son propre clone Segway sous FreeBSD. A lire pour plus de détails.

story.name: Des ports propres et sur mesures
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: L'auteur décrit comment "nettoyer" l'arborescence des ports et comment adapter les options de compilation des ports à l'aide des outils portupgrade.

story.name: FreeBSD vs. Linux sur TechTV ! Le duel des OS sur OffMyServer
story.author: Matt Olander
story.p: L'article montre comment, lors la dernière émission de TechTV "The Screen Savers show", FreeBSD a progressé par rapport à Linux.

story.name: Les Jails de FreeBSD
story.author: Mike DeGraw-Bertsch
story.p: Cet article explique comment installer et configurer les Jails sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Portupgrade
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: L'auteur explique comment installer et utiliser portupgrage pour mettre à jour les applications d'un système FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD et le JDK Java
story.author: Michael Singer
story.p: L'auteur discute des bénéfices qu'apporte le support natif de Java à FreeBSD.

story.name: Les Listes de Contrôle d'Accès de FreeBSD
story.author: Daniel Harris
story.p: L'auteur explique comment utiliser Les Listes de Contrôle d'Accès, une des nouvelles fonctionnalités de FreeBSD 5.X.

story.name: Astuces pour les Ports
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: Dans cette édition de FreeBSD Basics, Dru Lavigne expose ses astuces favorites concernant les ports.

story.name: Comparaison de différents systèmes d'exploitation orientés serveur
story.author: Jem Matzan
story.p: Une étude comparative de systèmes d'exploitation dans leur version serveur qu'ils soient gratuits ou propriétaires. L'article recommande fortement la famille des systèmes d'exploitation BSD au regard de leurs qualités.

story.name: Pourquoi les utilisateurs choisissent BSD plutôt que Linux ou des logiciels commerciaux
story.author: Ean Kingston
story.p: L'auteur recommande FreeBSD, insistant sur sa licence, sa simplicité, sa stabilité et la myriade d'applications disponibles.

story.name: Près de 2 millions de sites internet utilisent FreeBSD
story.author: Mike Prettejohn
story.p: Le nombre de sites utilisant FreeBSD s'accroit régulièrement. Netcraft fournit les statistiques et en donne les raisons.

story.name: Selon Netcraft, les meilleurs hébergeurs internet utilisent FreeBSD
story.author: les rédacteurs du site internet
story.p: Un rapport de Netcraft conclue que 5 des 10 meilleurs hébergeurs dans le monde utilisent le système d'exploitation FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD 5.1 présente des nouvelles caractéristiques très pratiques
story.author: Jason Brooks
story.p: Résumé des nouvelles caractéristiques de la branche 5.X, et notamment le nouveau service de gestion "jail".

story.name: Problèmes liés à l'installation de FreeBSD
story.author: Brian Tiemann, Michael Urban
story.p: Un guide d'installation détaillé de FreeBSD.

story.name: Le temps des BSD est-il venu ?
story.author: Jim Rapoza
story.p: L'auteur recommande l'adoption de la famille des systèmes d'exploitation BSD pour les projets de logiciels libres ayant trait aux technologies internet.

story.name: Les principales mesures de sécurité s'appliquant à FreeBSD
story.author: Szekely Ervin
story.p: L'article décrit les principales mesures à prendre concernant la sécurité des stations de travail sous FreeBSD 4.X.

story.name: Nouveau site de téléchargement pour FreeBSD
story.author: Les rédacteurs du site internet
story.p: Trois entreprises se rassemblent et montent un nouveau miroir du site internet FreeBSD et des services CVSup.

story.name: FreeBSD Foundation sort la version 5.1
story.author: Thor Olavsrud
story.p: L'article rapporte brièvement la sortie de FreeBSD 5.1.

story.name: Support de l'AMD64 pour bientôt
story.author: Arron Rouse
story.p: Un court article à propos du prochain support de la plate-forme AMD64 dans FreeBSD 5.x.

story.name: Par-delà Linux
story.author: Chad Dickerson
story.p: L'auteur recommande FreeBSD, faisant les louanges de sa pile TCP/IP et de sa licence libérale.

story.name: Zoom sur FreeBSD : entretien avec l'équipe principale
story.author: Eugenia Loli-Queru
story.p: OS News donne une interview approfondie de Wes Peters, Greg Lehey et Warner M. Losh de l'équipe principale de FreeBSD ainsi que de Scott Long, développeur. L'article aborde notamment le support de Java, la compétition avec Linux et la branche 5.x de FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD sur TechTV
story.author: Communiqué de presse de Offmyserver
story.p: Murray Stokely, membre de l'équipe principale de FreeBSD, a fait une apparition sur TechTV avec Matt Olander de Offmyserver pour parler de FreeBSD et réaliser une installation en direct à la télévision. Le communiqué de presse inclue un lien vers un flux RealVideo de cette émission.

story.name: FreeBSD 5.0 et les entreprises
story.author: Howard Dahdah
story.p: Linuxworld détaille les possibilités de FreeBSD 5.0 en tant que système d'exploitation d'entreprise et donne l'interview de Scott Long, développeur FreeBSD.

story.name: Petites choses diverses
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: Article de Dru Lavigne sur les façons les plus simples pour un nouvel utilisateur de se familiariser avec FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD 5.0 déchaîné
story.author: Michael Singer
story.p: Internetnews.com détaille FreeBSD 5.0 et donne l'interview de Murray Stokely, un membre de l'équipe technique en charge des nouvelles versions de FreeBSD.

story.name: "Opera Software" sort une version pour FreeBSD
story.author: Communiqué de presse de "Opera Software"
story.p: "Opera Software" a le plaisir d'annoncer la première version "officielle" du port FreeBSD de son logiciel.

story.name: Lecture de DVD sous FreeBSD
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: Dru Lavigne se plonge dans le monde de la lecture des DVD sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Les BSDs : sophistiqués, puissants et (le plus souvent) gratuits
story.author: Brett Glass
story.p: Un article sur l'historique et la culture des projets BSD.

story.name: Utilisation du son sous FreeBSD
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: Dru Lavigne décrit le processus de configuration du son sur un poste de travail multimédia FreeBSD.

story.name: BSD, un OS pour l'entreprise ? Et bien, oui
story.author: UNIX dans l'entreprise
story.p: Un court entretien avec Michael Lucas (un participant actif de FreeBSD) sur l'utilisation des BSD en entreprise.

story.name: Transformer FreeBSD en station multimédia
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: Dru Lavigne explique comment créer un poste de travail multimédia avec FreeBSD.

story.name: A la poursuite de Linux
story.author: Maggie Biggs
story.p: Maggie Biggs s'intéresse au futur FreeBSD 5.0 et découvre que ce système d'exploitation open-source s'est considérablement amélioré en ce qui concerne les outils et applications disponibles ainsi que sur la sécurité.

story.name: Interview avec Jordan Hubbard
story.author: Jeremy Andrews
story.p: Kerneltrap s'entretient avec Jordan Hubbard, un des créateurs de FreeBSD, et actuellement directeur du projet Darwin de Apple.

story.name: Multi-Boot FreeBSD et FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Michael Lucas décrit comment une machine peut être configurée en multi-boot avec FreeBSD -CURRENT et -STABLE.

story.name: Jordan Hubbard quitte l'équipe dirigeante de FreeBSD
story.author: Gregory Sutter
story.p: Jordan Hubbard, co-fondateur de FreeBSD, quitte l'équipe dirigeante.

story.name: Technologie à la Carte
story.author: Bill Nicholls
story.p: Un article sur FreeBSD 4.5 avec mention de la "pré-version développeurs" de FreeBSD 5.0.

story.name: Tester FreeBSD-Current
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Le committer Michael Lucas donne un aperçu de la première pré-version destinée aux développeurs de FreeBSD 5.0.

story.name: Connexion IPv6 avec FreeBSD
story.author: David LeCount
story.p: Comment utiliser freenet6 de la collection des ports pour réaliser un tunnel IPv6 sous IPv4.

story.name: Paniques système, deuxième partie : Réparation et Déboguage
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Michael Lucas décrit quoi faire lorsqu'une panique système survient. C'est la seconde partie de l'article; la partie 1 décrivait comment préparer un système FreeBSD à gérer les paniques.

story.name: Configurer un point d'accès FreeBSD pour votre réseau sans fil
story.author: Michael S. DeGraw-Bertsch
story.p: Des instructions pour configurer de manière sécurisée un PC sous FreeBSD en tant que passerelle entre un réseau 802.11b et un réseau cablé traditionnel.

story.name: Défaillance d'une campagne anti-Unix
story.author: Matt Berger
story.p: Reportages de InfoWorld sur l'utilisation de FreeBSD pour un serveur web créé à l'occasion d'une campagne publicitaire "remarquable".

story.name: Un guide multimédia pour FreeBSD
story.author: Tracey J. Rosenblath
story.p: Comment configurer et utiliser le support audio sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Paniques système, première partie : Se préparer pour le pire
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Préparer un système FreeBSD à gérer une panique système.

story.name: Comprendre CVSup, le montage des périphériques, les ports et le système d'initialisations sous FreeBSD
story.author: Nathan Mace
story.p: Un article pour configurer et maintenir une installation FreeBSD.

story.name: Vous voulez une alternative à Windows ? Essayez BSD
story.author: Stephan Somogyi
story.p: Une introduction non-technique à la famille BSD (excepté BSD/OS).

story.name: Find : seconde partie
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: A la recherche de vos fichiers avec la commande find.

story.name: Construire un firewall sur CD Bootable
story.author: Etienne de Bruin
story.p: Des instructions pour construire un système FreeBSD qui démarre depuis un CD-ROM. Son utilisation en tant que firewall est mentionné.

story.name: IPv6 rencontre FreeBSD
story.author: Mike DeGraw-Bertsch
story.p: Un aperçu de la configuration IPv6 sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Retrouver les choses sous Unix
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: S'initier à la commande find.

story.name: Comprendre NFS
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Utiliser NFS sous FreeBSD.

story.name: Comment devenir un membre actif ("committer") de FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Michael détaille le processus pour devenir un committer FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD Week: Migrating from Linux to FreeBSD
story.author: Nathan Mace
story.p: A guide for users migrating from Linux to FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD Week: Interview with Robert Watson
story.author: Eugenia Loli-Queru
story.p: An interview with Robert Watson, member of FreeBSD's core and security on the upcoming FreeBSD 4.5 and FreeBSD 5.0 releases.

story.name: American Megatrends Inc. Releases Latest Version of StorTrends NAS Software
story.author: AMI Press Release
story.p: American Megatrends Inc. announced the release of StoreTrends(tm) NAS software version 1.1, which is based on FreeBSD.

story.name: Contributing to BSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Michael Lucas shows what it takes for non-coders to contribute to BSD.

story.name: A basic guide to securing FreeBSD 4.x-STABLE
story.author: Marc Silver
story.p: This article is for system administrators. It explains how to configure and maintain a FreeBSD system for high security.

story.name: FreeBSD to change hands
story.author: Stephen Shankland CNET
story.p: Wind River Systems announces the transfer of its FreeBSD assets to the FreeBSD Mall.

story.name: Kerneltrap Interview with Matt Dillon
story.author: Jeremy Andrews
story.p: Kerneltrap interviews Matt Dillon, one of FreeBSD's key developers.

story.name: Microsoft Hotmail still runs on U**x
story.author: Andrew Orlowski
story.p: Nearly four years after it was acquired by Microsoft, and in spite of a well-publicized effort to migrate it to Windows and IIS, Hotmail is still partly based on FreeBSD and Apache.

story.name: Keeping Your Options Open: FreeBSD as a Workstation for UNIX Newbies
story.author: Eugenia Loli-Queru
story.p: An article discussing FreeBSD as an workstation OS for new Unix users.

story.name: Cleaning Up Ports
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A brief introduction to portupgrade.

story.name: Stable SMB
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A short article on accessing a Windows(R) share from a FreeBSD workstation.

story.name: FreeBSD Versus Linux Revisited
story.author: Moshe Bar
story.p: Byte's Moshe Bar does a comparison, through informal benchmarks, of FreeBSD 4.3 to Linux 2.4.10 running sendmail, procmail, MySQL, and Apache. The emphasis of the article is examination of the newly rewritten VM system in Linux, so the tests are conducted with only 512 MB of RAM.

story.name: The Big *BSD Interview
story.author: Eugenia Loli-Queru
story.p: An interview with Matt Dillon, a key developer in FreeBSD on the upcoming features in FreeBSD 5.0.

story.name: Running Windows applications on FreeBSD
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: A short article on running Windows(R) applications under WINE in FreeBSD.

story.name: Dealing with Full Disks
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A short article on dealing with the all too common full disk.

story.name: Ripping MP3s
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A short article on ripping CDs on FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD Anti-Virus Protection - A Commercial Alternative
story.author: Jeremiah Gowdy
story.p: This is a review of Kaspersky Anti-Virus for FreeBSD, a product which can protect a network of Microsoft Windows hosts by scanning e-mail and SMB file shares.

story.name: CVS Mirror
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: How to mirror the FreeBSD CVS repository.

story.name: CVSup Infrastructure
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An article on FreeBSD's CVSup infrastructure used to distribute its source code worldwide.

story.name: An Interview with Jordan Hubbard
story.author: pairNetworks
story.p: An short interview with Jordan Hubbard, one of the founders of the FreeBSD project.

story.name: Controlling Bandwidth
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using DUMMYNET to control bandwidth allocation

story.name: Which OS is Fastest for High-Performance Network Applications?
story.author: Jeffrey B. Rothman and John Buckman
story.p: Linux, Solaris, FreeBSD and Windows 2000 are benchmarked for network applications. This article has a sequel where the tests were redone after tuning FreeBSD.

story.name: NAI Labs Announces DARPA-Funded FreeBSD Security Initiative
story.author: NAI Labs Press Release
story.p: NAI Labs, a division of Network Associates, Inc., announced a $1.2 million contract awarded by the U.S. Navy's Space and Warfare Systems Command to develop security extensions to the Open Source FreeBSD operating system.

story.name: Controlling User Logins
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An article describing the ways to control user access to your FreeBSD system.

story.name: Rotating Log Files
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using the functionality of newsyslog in FreeBSD.

story.name: Microsoft's FreeBSD Move Aimed At Next Generation Of Developers
story.author: Paula Rooney
story.p: A report on Microsoft's venture to port its C# programming language to FreeBSD.

story.name: BSD guru to guide Apple on Unix
story.author: Macworld (UK) staff
story.p: Apple (http://www.apple.com/) has recruited FreeBSD founder Jordan Hubbard to its team, in a bid to steer its Mac OS X BSD (Berkeley Software Distribution) efforts.

story.name: Microsoft Uses Open-Source Code Despite Denying Use of Such Software
story.author: Lee Gomes
story.p: An article which states that open-source software connected with the FreeBSD operating system is used in several places deep inside several versions of Microsoft's Windows software, and on numerous server computers that manage major functions at Microsoft's free e-mail service, Hotmail.

story.name: In your face! MS open source attacks backfire
story.author: Lee Gomes
story.p: A report on the backfiring of the Microsoft effort to vilify open source software.

story.name: System Logging
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: System logging in FreeBSD using syslogd.

story.name: BSD Tricks: CVS
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using CVS in client-mode.

story.name: Setting up Wireless Cards on FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Configuring FreeBSD for wireless operation.

story.name: FreeBSD Gaming
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A survey of the games available in the FreeBSD ports collection.

story.name: Submitting Changes
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Submitting change requests to the FreeBSD project using send-pr.

story.name: Changing FreeBSD Documentation
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A mini tutorial on DocBook and its use by the FreeBSD Documentation Project.

story.name: The FreeBSD Documentation Project
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An introduction to the FreeBSD project.

story.name: For Servers: Linux 2.4 vs. FreeBSD 4.1.1
story.author: Moshe Bar
story.p: BYTE's Linux guru finds himself wondering why he isn't running FreeBSD --- a comparision (with informal benchmarks) of FreeBSD 4.1.1 and a Linux based distribution running the v2.4.0 Linux kernel.

story.name: Modifying a Port
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Howto modify a FreeBSD port.

story.name: Fine Control of Ports
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A system administrator's view of the Ports system.

story.name: Is FreeBSD a Superior Server Platform to Linux?
story.author: Nathan Boeger
story.p: A reviewer finds FreeBSD 4.1 to be better suited for web serving than a Red Hat Linux distribution.

story.name: A Roundtable on BSD, Security, and Quality
story.author: Jack J. Woehr
story.p: A report from a roundtable at the recent USENIX Security Symposium 2000, involving several prominent developers in the BSD world.

story.name: BSD Ports Collection Basics
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: How the FreeBSD Ports collection works.

story.name: BSD Tricks: Unprepared Disaster Recovery
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: How to recover files off of FreeBSD system.

story.name: Open-sourcing the Apple
story.author: Jordan Hubbard
story.p: A geek's appraisal of the Apple OS X from Jordan Hubbard, one of the lead developers on the FreeBSD project.

story.name: BSD Tricks: Linux Compatibility, the Hard Way
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using a Linux install under FreeBSD's Linux compatibility mode.

story.name: Laptops, PC Cards and FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using FreeBSD on a laptop.

story.name: BSD Tricks: Introductory Revision Control
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Using RCS for file revision control.

story.name: BSD OSs Offer Unix Alternatives to Linux
story.author: Bill Nicholls
story.p: This column gives an overview of the different versions of BSD, with links for more information.

story.name: INTERNET'S BUSIEST OPENSOURCE SOFTWARE ARCHIVE SETS NEW DOWNLOAD RECORD
story.author: TeraSolutions Press Release
story.p: TeraSolutions, Inc. and Lightning Internet Services announce that the OpenSource archive at ftp.freesoftware.com has surpassed the download milestone of two trillion bytes per day from a single server machine.

story.name: BSD Tricks: MFS
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: A short article on using the FreeBSD Memory Filesystem.

story.name: TRUSTING BSD - Ultra-High Security for FreeBSD
story.author: Jeffrey Carl
story.p: An interview with Robert Watson, one of the lead developers in the TrustedBSD project.

story.name: More FreeBSD Comics
story.author: Illiad
story.p: See also the comics for the 8th, 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th.

story.name: Experiments in SMB
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An early review of FreeBSD's SMB support.

story.name: Installing OCSweb on FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An article on a developers experience porting software from Linux to FreeBSD.

story.name: The State of the Daemon
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An informative article on BSD, and where it is going.

story.name: Server Goliaths Turn to Appliance Servers
story.author: Adam Darby
story.p: An article evaluating various commercial OSes that contains a blurb about BSDI and FreeBSD.

story.name: FreeBSD: Serving the World
story.author: James Howard
story.p: With the recent hype surrounding open source software, an important project has gone unnoticed in the media. This project, FreeBSD, aims to create a rock-solid UNIX clone based on the 4BSD work from the University of California at Berkeley.

story.name: Riding the Web Wave
story.author: Henry Norr
story.p: FreeBSD, a relatively unknown operating system is playing a big role on the Internet.

story.name: BSD Unix: Power to the people, from the code
story.author: Andrew Leonard
story.p: How Berkeley hackers built the Net's most fabled free operating system on the ashes of the '60s---and then lost the lead to Linux.

story.name: Install FreeBSD 4.0 in seven easy steps
story.author: Dru Lavigne
story.p: A short guide to installing FreeBSD 4.0.

story.name: Partial Reunification May Give BSD New Visibility
story.author: Dominique Deckmyn
story.p: Compares the merged Walnut Creek/BSDI OS offering to Linux.

story.name: Developers using open-source software behind bosses' backs
story.author: Peter Wayner
story.p: Open-source software sometimes provides a better solution than expensive commerical, closed software.

story.name: FreeBSD 4.0 Now Includes PolyServe's High Availability Clustering & Load Balancing Software
story.author: PolyServe Press Release
story.p: PolyServe, a provider of software-based, distributed server clustering technology, announced co-marketing agreement with FreeBSD, Inc. to ship PolyServe's Understudy (TM) software program with all new versions of FreeBSD 4.0 operating system software.

story.name: BSDI Getting the Word Out
story.author: Alexandra Barrett
story.p: Talks of the lack of awareness in the market of the strengths of the BSD operating system and of the plans afoot to change this.

story.name: The New BSDI to Offer Technical Support for the FreeBSD Operating System
story.author: BSDi Press Release
story.p: BSDi will be offering technical support contracts for FreeBSD beginning in May 2000.

story.name: Commentary: BSD sleight of hand
story.author: Stephan Somogyi
story.p: Commentary on the BSDI/FreeBSD merger.

story.name: FreeBSD 3.4 Review, Part 2: Adopting the Daemon
story.author: Clifford Smith
story.p: The second part of a review of FreeBSD v3.4.

story.name: The legend of BSD
story.author: Annalee Newitz
story.p: An interview with three BSD veterans on the past and future of BSD.

story.name: Bostic on the BSD tradition
story.author: Dale Dougherty
story.p: An interview with BSD veteran Keith Bostic on the BSDI/FreeBSD merger. ``BSD has always had the best technology'', says Keith.

story.name: Customizing the FreeBSD Kernel
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Michael Lucas presents a guide to customizing the FreeBSD kernel, written for the Linux oriented.

story.name: FreeBSD for the SVR4/Linux Administrator
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: This article attempts to give a System V or Linux administrator a basic grounding in FreeBSD configuration and usage.

story.name: FreeBSD Ports and Packages System Explained
story.author: Bill Swingle
story.p: A good description of the FreeBSD Ports collection.

story.name: Business Lessons From Online Porn
story.author: Richard A. Glidewell
story.p: Praise for FreeBSD from this article: ``FreeBSD is the system of choice because it is fast, stable, and can handle large volumes of traffic.''

story.name: Crazed Ferrets in a Berkeley Shower
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: An article on the BSD License.

story.name: Three Unixlike systems may be better than Linux
story.author: Simson L. Garfinkel
story.p: Promotes the BSD OSes as better alternatives to Linux in the areas of performance, reliability and security.

story.name: Buddying up to BSD: Part Five - FreeBSD Continued
story.author: Matt Michie
story.p: A Linux user writes about his experiences with the FreeBSD ports system.

story.name: Review of FreeBSD 3.4
story.author: Clifford Smith
story.p: A review of FreeBSD 3.4.

story.name: FreeBSD 4.0 And Beyond
story.author: Jeffrey Carl
story.p: A Jordan Hubbard Interview on Improvements, New Platforms and What's to Come.

story.name: Buddying up to BSD: Part Four - FreeBSD
story.author: Matt Michie
story.p: A Linux user writes about his experiences with FreeBSD.

story.name: Debunking Open-Source Myths: Origins and Players
story.author: N. Drakos and M. Driver
story.p: A report that looks at and debunks some of the myths associated with Open Source development.

story.name: Linux Scales Enterprise Wall
story.author: Mitch Wagner
story.p: About 17 percent of enterprises plan to deploy FreeBSD or Linux as a primary platform for e-commerce within two years.

story.name: Jobs announces new MacOS, becomes 'iCEO'
story.author: CNN news article
story.p: Steve Jobs' Macworld Expo keynote speech mentions FreeBSD as one of the components in the new Darwin OS from Apple.

story.name: Mac OS X
story.author: Apple communication
story.p: In an article on the next generation Darwin OS, Apple Inc., refers to FreeBSD as one of the ``most acclaimed OS projects of the modern era.''

story.name: Linux under FreeBSD
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: FreeBSD has several options for using software from other platforms such as Linux. This article examines Linux emulation under FreeBSD.

story.name: Freei.Net Doubles Service Speed With Intel(R) Server Platforms
story.author: Freei.Net Press Release
story.p: Freei.Net is purchasing hundreds of Intel's LB440GX 2U Rack Server Platforms as the Internet service provider continues to experience explosive growth in its subscriber base. ``The LB440GX flawlessly supports our FreeBSD operating system,'' said Steve Bourg, Freei.Net's Chief Technical Officer.

story.name: FreeBSD 3.3. Robust OS well suited for Internet/Intranet Deployment
story.author: Juha Saarinen
story.p: Linux administrator turns to FreeBSD and finds it impressive.

story.name: FreeBSD at COMDEX
story.author: Brett Glass
story.p: Brett Glass sent this message to the FreeBSD -chat mailing list, about his experiences and perceptions at COMDEX. Of particular interest are the problems he had trying to get vendors to support the BSDs and Linux.

story.name: Who controls free software?
story.author: Andrew Leonard
story.p: Discusses RedHat's acquisition of Cygnus, quotes Jordan Hubbard at length, and mentions FreeBSD.

story.name: The Darwinist: Darwin for x86?
story.author: Stephan Somogyi
story.p: A report on Wilfredo Sanchez's session on FreeBSD and the Apple Darwin project at the first FreeBSDCon.

story.name: Bob Frankenberg's breaking Windows
story.author: Michael Tarsala
story.p: In an interview with CBS MarketWatch, Bob Frankenberg, ex-CEO of Novell, praises FreeBSD for doing ``an exceptionally good job''. FreeBSD is used in his current company, Encanto.

story.name: Applix and Walnut Creek Partner to Provide Applixware Office for the FreeBSD Operating System
story.author: Applix Inc. press release
story.p: Walnut Creek will distribute Applixware Office v4.4.2 in their FreeBSD 3.3 Power Desktop product. In addition, Walnut Creek will bundle Applix'SHELF, a visual open-source application development toolset and runtime environment with FreeBSD.

story.name: LinuxWorld report on FreeBSDCon 99
story.author: Vicki Brown
story.p: October 17, 1999 marked a milestone in the history of FreeBSD -- the first FreeBSD conference was held in the city where it all began.

story.name: FreeBSDCon'99: Fans of Linux's lesser-known sibling gather for the first time
story.author: Vicki Brown
story.p: Repost of IDG article about FreeBSDCon '99.

story.name: ServerWatch's Review of FreeBSD
story.author: Kevin Reichard
story.p: FreeBSD v3.2 is as close to the perfect Internet server operating system as it comes.

story.name: Grass Roots Daemocracy
story.author: Sam Williams
story.p: A report from the first annual FreeBSDCon held in Berkeley, California.

story.name: ENTERA DELIVERS FreeBSD STREAMING SERVER SUPPORTING QUICKTIME
story.author: Entera Press Release
story.p: Entera announces a free, standards-based RTSP/RTP server to stream QuickTime from a FreeBSD platform.

story.name: Open Source Software Development as a Special Type of Academic Research
story.author: Nikolai Bezroukov
story.p: This paper tries to explore links between open source software development and academic research as a better paradigm for OSS development.
Claims that the operating systems based on BSD are more reliable and secure. (requires registration with The Boston Globe prior to viewing)

story.name: Beyond Linux, Free Systems Help Build The Web
story.author: Lee Gomes
story.p: An introduction to the BSD family of free operating systems.

story.name: Maintaining Patch Levels with Open Source BSDs
story.author: Michael Lucas
story.p: Focusses on the BSD development model and the ease of keeping upto-date with tools like sup and CVSup.

story.name: Out of Linux limelight, devil gets its due
story.author: Hiawatha Bray
story.p: A short (but not very accurate) introduction to FreeBSD for people who have heard about Linux.

story.name: Reporter's notebook: Hackers on holiday
story.author: Ann Harrison
story.p: CNN reports that the winner during the "Linux Death Match" at the Chaos Computer Camp in Germany used FreeBSD tools to win out over Linux attackers. More details are available at http://www.42.org/~sec/Berichte/199908Camp/index.en.html#match.

story.name: More FreeBSD Comics
story.author: Illiad
story.p:
See also the comics for the
4th and the
5th.

story.name: World's Biggest Internet Search Engine Goes Online
story.author: FAST Press Release
story.p:
Said to be the largest search engine on the Internet, FAST Web Search
uses the FreeBSD operating system.

story.name: Duke Computer Scientists Exceed "Gigabit" Data Processing Speeds With Internet Software
story.author: Duke University press release
story.p: Using FreeBSD, Duke University computer science researchers have developed a system for communication at speeds higher than one billion bits per second in a local area network of personal computers. More details can be found at the Trapeze project web site.

story.name: WORLDS LARGEST INDEPENDENT IPP HITS NEW MILESTONE
story.author: pair Networks press release
story.p: pair Networks, Inc., the World's largest independently owned and operated paid hosting service, today announced that it has surpassed the 60,000 Web site milestone. Their web servers in their state-of-the-art data center house more than 2 Terabytes of storage, and deliver up to 100 million hits per day to site visitors. pair uses FreeBSD in order to ensure maximum uptime and reliability.

story.name: Free OS? It' s as easy as BSD
story.author: Peter McGarvey
story.p: Network manager Peter McGarvey writes about his experience with a number of varieties of Unix. He sums up: FreeBSD is the greatest.

story.name: BSD a better OS than Linux?
story.author: Bob Sullivan
story.p: BSD is the software behind the world's most popular Web site and the world's most popular FTP site.

story.name: The Net's stealth operating system
story.author: Bob Sullivan
story.p: BSD powers some of the biggest sites, and its users are among the most jealous of Linux.

story.name: Embed Together: The Case For BSD In Network Appliances
story.author: Kevin Rose and Charles Davidson
story.p: Underlines the advantages of BSD for the embedded device market. Mentions picoBSD.

story.name: Radio interview: Linux and FreeBSD
story.author: Chris DiBona and Jordan Hubbard
story.p: Chris DiBona of VA Research and Jordan Hubbard of the FreeBSD Project give their views on Linux and FreeBSD.

story.name: Thin Servers
story.author: Ted Drude
story.p: A survey of thin servers, featuring products using FreeBSD as their internal operating system.

story.name: Information Technology and the Internet in Co-operation Ireland
story.author: Interview with Michael Doyle
story.p: Michael Doyle, system administrator for Co-operation Ireland roots for FreeBSD in this interview. Michael is using FreeBSD and PostgreSQL as a cost-effective and ultra-reliable solution for his organization's I.T. needs.

story.name: GPL and BSD: explication and comparison
story.author: Rob Bos
story.p: An article comparing BSD and GPL style licenses.

story.name: CmdrTaco on Slashdot Sale
story.author: Leander Kahney
story.p: In an interview with Wired News, Rob Malda, founder of Slashdot, says that he would now like to spend some more time reporting on FreeBSD.

story.name: Server Platforms - FreeBSD Review
story.author: Kevin Reichard
story.p: FreeBSD: Is it the perfect Internet server operating system? As close as it comes.

story.name: Yes! There is intelligent life beyond Linux
story.author: David Cartwright
story.p: It looks like Unix, it tastes like Unix but it isn't Unix. It's FreeBSD!

story.name: Silicon Carny: Why I run FreeBSD
story.author: Rich Morin
story.p: Rich Morin explains why FreeBSD is the superior OS for him.

story.name: INTERNET'S BUSIEST SOFTWARE ARCHIVE REACHES NEW DOWNLOAD MILESTONE
story.author: David Greenman
story.p: Walnut Creek CDROM, Inc. announces that their popular software archive at ftp://ftp.cdrom.com has surpassed the one trillion bytes (one terabyte) milestone of files downloaded per day from a single server machine.

story.name: Bye-Bye, Windows
story.author: Christopher Lindquist
story.p: Reviews alternative PC operating systems. Includes a review of FreeBSD 3.2.

story.name: Gnome is no Windows dwarf
story.author: Chris Nuttall
story.p: Article on Gnome and the Open Source movement. Mentions FreeBSD.

story.name: OS Also-Rans
story.author: JULIO OJEDA-ZAPATA
story.p: A short article introducing a few alternative OSes, including FreeBSD and OpenBSD. Aimed at the general public.

story.name: Micron Electronics NetFRAME chosen for Internet's busiest site
story.author: David Greenman
story.p: During its first full day of operation, the new NetFRAME 9201 server set a new all-time one day download record of 969GB of files, surpassing the previous record set last year of 873GB/day.

story.name: The other open-source OS: FreeBSD
story.author: Anne Chen
story.p: Examples of FreeBSD deployment in the real world and why some technology officers find it attractive.

story.name: Open-Source Software: Power to the People
story.author: Lee Bruno
story.p: Linux and BSD Unix are starting to show up on more and more corporate servers, running alongside or even replacing Netware and Windows NT.

story.name: XML: Complete XML Development System Integrated with FreeBSD
story.author: Jordan Hubbard
story.p: Included with FreeBSD 3.1 is a complete, integrated SGML/XML development system that installs with a simple, easy to use command sequence.

story.name: Inktomi Announces Traffic Server 3.0
story.author: Inktomi press release
story.p: FreeBSD is a supported operating system for a new version of Inktomi's carrier-class network cache platform.

story.name: The Matrix: FreeBSD Used to Generate Special Effects
story.author: Jordan Hubbard
story.p: Dual-Processor FreeBSD systems were used to generate a large number of special effects in the cutting edge Warner Brothers film, The Matrix.

story.name: Let's Get More Educated About FreeBSD
story.author: Preston S. Wiley
story.p: A system administrator shares his views on FreeBSD.

story.name: The Oldest Free OS
story.author: Steven J. Vaughan-Nichols
story.p: What are the oldest free operating systems around? The answer is the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) Unix variants.

story.name: FreeBSD wants a place in the sun
story.author: Sam Williams
story.p: Introduces FreeBSD to Linux users.

story.name: FreeBSD Offers a Sound Open Source Alternative
story.author: James C. Luh
story.p: Outside technical circles, many remain unaware of viable choices for internet servers---like the FreeBSD operating system that drives Web servers for such high-profile names as Yahoo and Best Internet Communications (now part of Verio).

story.name: Serious FTP: Behind the scenes of Walnut Creek CDROM
story.author: Rich Morin
story.p:
A description of the Walnut Creek CDROM setup. The article is also available from
SunWorld.

story.name: Thin Servers: Off-the-Shelf Internet Help
story.author: Christine Zimmerman
story.p: Discusses thin-servers, including six built using an embedded FreeBSD kernel.

story.name: A FreeBSD Comic Strip
story.author: Illiad
story.p: See also the serial from the 22nd, 23rd, 24th, 25th, 26th, and 27th of March, 1999.

story.name: Rising support for BSD
story.author: Nathan Cochrane
story.p: Columnist Nathan Cochrane talks about the BSD family of open source operating systems.

story.name: Whence the Source: Untangling the Open Source/Free Software Debate
story.author: Thomas Scoville
story.p: An article on the open-source / free-software debate. Mentions Berkeley Unix as one of the early successes of shared source code collaboration.

story.name: LWN interviews Alan Cox
story.p: There is a small but interesting FreeBSD mention in LWN in an interview with Linux's Alan Cox.
Software that has been developed by thousands of volunteers and is given away is often better than the stuff for sale. Note: The article is no longer available online without registration.

story.name: Twenty Years of Berkeley Unix
story.author: Marshall Kirk McKusick
story.p: A short history of Berkeley Unix.

story.name: WWWsmith: Installation and Configuration of FreeBSD
story.author: Sean Eric Fagan
story.p: Here is how to set up a web server using another freely available operating system, FreeBSD, a high performance, mature, Unix-like system.

story.name: The return of BSD - What are the BSD flavors and why might you use them?
story.author: Greg Lehey
story.p: Introduces the modern BSD OSes to the general public.

While finished thin servers should be optimized in both hardware and software for the task at hand, who says the software and hardware must come from the same developer? This Perspective examines the emerging trend in the OEM market of divorcing the software layer from the hardware layer. Many operating systems are vying to be the OS of choice for thin servers. This document examines this issue in detail, particularly the differences between Linux and FreeBSD, the current de facto leaders in the market. Note: The article is no longer available online without registration.

story.name: Nature Web Matters: Internet tomography
story.author: K.C. Claffy, Tracie Monk & Daniel McRobb, UCSD/CAIDA, USA.
story.p: The article describes a network management tool built on FreeBSD that has even used network connections to www.FreeBSD.org for performing network research.

story.name: The story on FreeBSD
story.author: Cameron Laird and Kathryn Soraiz
story.p: This issue has a good article on FreeBSD and why it's worth a look by Linux folks.

story.name: The Open-Source Revolution
story.author: Tim O'Reilly, with an introduction by Esther Dyson
story.p: A brief, business oriented introduction to the open source community.

story.name: Report from Comdex--Walnut Creek CDROM, FreeBSD and Slackware
story.author: Dwight Johnson
story.p: There is a good report on the Walnut Creek booth and FreeBSD at the Linux Today website. The first half of the report is on Slackware Linux, the second half is on FreeBSD.

story.name: Ellison plans hardware, bashes Bill
story.author: Tim Clark
story.p: Larry Ellison talking about their new dedicated Oracle servers, mentions FreeBSD as one of a list of candidate OSes for the platform.

story.name: Linux/etc, The other free Unixes, part 2 of 2
story.author: Terry Griffin
story.p: Continuation of an earlier column reviewing freely available Unix like operating systems.

story.name: What Is FreeBSD?
story.author: Jordan K. Hubbard
story.p: An introduction to FreeBSD, and where it stands with respect to the other free OSes.

story.name: Unix back in the fight with NT
story.author: Miguel Helft
story.p: An article touting the stability and power of the Unix platform over NT.

story.name: A No-Cost NOS
story.author: Ryan Snedegar
story.p: Ryan Snedegar reviews FreeBSD 2.2.7 and finds its web-serving performance to be better than Windows NT.

story.name: Open Code Frees Up The Net
story.author: Charles Babcock
story.p: About why customers prefer open source software like Linux, FreeBSD, Perl and TCL to proprietary alternatives.

story.name: It's only free Unix - but I like it
story.author: David Malone

story.name: Linux/etc, The other free Unixes, part 1 of 2
story.author: Terry Griffin
story.p: Briefly reviews the BSD Unix heritage.

story.name: Communications & Networking: Asynchronous Communications Using select and poll
story.author: Sean Eric Fagan
story.p: On how to use FreeBSD's select(2) and poll(2) system calls.

story.name: Quality Unix for FREE
story.author: Brett Glass
story.p: A short introduction to FreeBSD 2.2.7.

story.name: Hack raises flags about small ISPs
story.author: Jim Hu, Staff Writer, CNET NEWS.COM
story.p: Desire for better security has led some ISPs to deploy FreeBSD on their servers.

story.name: Walnut Creek CDROM, One of the Largest Public FTP Archives in the World, Sets Traffic Record Using FreeBSD and Colocating on CRL's High-Speed Internet Network
story.author: CRL Press Release

story.name: Pulling on one end of the rope
story.author: Jordan K. Hubbard
story.p: Jordan compares the past of Unix with the future of Linux, outlining possible similarities and describing faults that could be prevented.

story.name: Nader urges Windows probe
story.author: Jeff Pelline
story.p: Consumer-rights advocate Ralph Nader mentions FreeBSD by name.

story.name: Stone's Throw, Issue Fourteen: Home of the Brave, Land of the FreeBSD
story.author: Andrew Stone

story.name: Load Balancing Your Web Site
story.author: Ralf S.Engelschall
story.p: Practical approaches to distributing HTTP traffic at your site. Includes a section on performance tuning Apache under FreeBSD.

story.name: Is NT paranoid or is Unix out to get it?
story.author: Nicholas Petreley

story.name: Security Tools in FreeBSD
story.author: Guy Helmer

story.name: Free Unix: Do You Get What You Pay For?
story.author: G. Weiss

story.name: The new Unix alters NT's orbit
story.author: Nicholas Petreley

story.name: Who's Serving Who?
story.author: Nels Johnson
story.p: For smaller companies and web sites, a FreeBSD and Apache on an Intel (PC) architecture machine is more than sufficient.

story.name: Searching for the next Windows NT
story.author: Nicholas Petreley

story.name: Benchmarking and Software Testing: Tracing BSD System Calls
story.author: Sean Eric Fagan
story.p: Note: the article is not available online.

story.name: Five alternative operating systems reviewed
story.author: Cormac Foster

story.name: Source code for the masses
story.author: Alex Lash

story.name: The Network Community
story.author: Ted Mittelstaedt

story.name: The Politics of NC Computing According to Oracle
story.author: Rawn Shaw

story.name: Assorted Security Tips for UNIX
story.author: Arthur Donkers
story.p: A collection of tips and tricks to secure your internal network.
